ratings.comment: With a dry sense of humor and a vast knowledge of the time, Stern made up for his choppy (and often silent) lectures with sharp wit that would often make you laugh. That being said, he was not the best lecturer and I often found myself bored despite the interesting topic and readings. He asks for participation, but did not know how to get it.

I really like Professor Stern. I thought the lectures were very informative even though he "uhm" more times than anyone else ever. I got the just of the readings pretty well just by attending every class. If you show up and pay attention, you'll do fine. If you don't, good luck. Also, he gives you the questions ahead of the exams.

Professor Stern is very knowledgeable and passionate. The lectures were interesting, though the first 15ish minutes reviewed the content of the previous lecture, which became monotonous. He does a nice job of making the sometimes dense readings understandable. Part of his grading is based on 'creativity' but still easy to score well.

Jewish 225 - I will say that Professor Stern is a caring professor. From the first lecture I knew my Jewish 225 class was going to be an interesting one. He cares about your well being if you make an effort to improve and learn the subject. Would highly recommend to those looking to challenge themselves while learning. His vocab is off the charts.
Weekly assignments that determine most of your grade, a cumulative final but he gives the questions he's going to ask beforehand, tough grader.

Very respectable and great guy to have as a professor. You can tell he genuinely cares about his students and has a lot of enthusiasm for the course material. Lectures can be monotonous at times as they go over weekly readings, but I found them to be helpful in summarizing and remembering the readings from the week.
Long lectures, can get boring at times but easiest class I took in all of college. Grades based on incomplete/complete and a C or above is complete. Very easy

Graded by complete/incomplete, so if you do your work and take basic notes in class you'll do well. A little bit of a stickler on things -- gave us assigned seats, but that was due to a group of super disrespectful people. Very very very knowledgeable, very smart, fairly engaging. Kind guy, wish my peers respected him more

I loved having Adam as a professor! He's very passionate with his teaching and always come to class very prepared and organized. His class required heavy reading but during lectures he recaps the readings well. We would have small group discussions every class and then come back together to relay what was talked about. Loved his grading scale too!

He's very articulate and skilled with explaining difficult concepts. He tried his best to facilitate conversations online and he's skilled at withstanding silence! Readings were interesting and a fair amount of writing. Learned a lot from Prof Stern. You need to work for your grade.

Good guy and knowledgeable, but as the last post said, this class didn't adapt well to an online format (in-person might be more enjoyable). Was reading and discussion-based, but the discussions were mainly summarizing the readings. Not much debate or deep analysis that I expected from a philosophy class. A TON of reading. Learned a lot though!

I don't think he's a bad professor at all. He seems to care about his students and wants the best for them. He is obviously very intelligent. I just think that his class didn't adapt well to the online format. It was very discussion-based and it's hard to encourage participation over Zoom. There's a lot of reading, but you can get by with skimming.
